content.text:
<image 1> The structural formula of the glycinium cation is shown above. Arrows indicate the $pK_a$ values for the labile protons in the molecule. Which of the following is true about the geometry of the glycinium cation?

A. The leftmost C atom and all the atoms directly bonded to it lie in the same plane. 
B. Both C atoms and both O atoms lie in the same plane. 
C. The N-C-C bond angle is 180°.
D. The geometry around the N atom is planar.

To determine the geometry of the glycinium cation, we need to consider the structure and the $pK_a$ values of the labile protons. The glycinium cation is the cationic form of glycine, which has the following structure:

\[
\text{H}_2\text{N}-\text{CH}_2\text{COOH}^+
\]

The $pK_a$ values indicate the stability of the protonated forms of the molecule. The lower $pK_a$ value ( (2.3) corresponds to the carboxyl group (COOH, which is more acidic and thus more stable. The higher $pK_a$ value ( (9.6) corresponds to the amine group (NH2, which is less acidic and thus less stable.

The geometry of the glycinium cation can be determined by considering the bonding and the presence of lone pairs on the nitrogen and oxygen atoms. The nitrogen atom has a lone pair, and the oxygen atoms in the carboxyl group also lone pairs. These lone pairs will affect the geometry around the nitrogen atom.

Given the presence of lone pairs on the nitrogen and oxygen atoms, the geometry around the nitrogen atom will be tetrahedral, not planar. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

Options A, B, and C are not directly related to the geometry of the glycinium cation. The geometry of the glycinium cation is not specified by the planarity of the leftmost C atom, both C atoms, or both O atoms, nor is it the N-C-C bond angle specified as 180°.

Thus, the correct answer is:

D. The geometry around the N atom is planar.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
